name: building operation, hostel | building operation, hostel | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21455/documentation

This dataset represents the operation of a tourist accommodation facility classed as a hostel, located in Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil.  It was first opened in 2016 although the building where the hostel resides was constructed in 1959. Prior to becoming a hostel, the building was used as residence. The hostel has the capacity to host 30 guests and offers rooms of the following types (total number of rooms is given in brackets): double (2) and shared use (3). The hostel has 3 floors with a games room in the underground, a lobby and a pool on the ground floor, and the bedrooms and kitchen in the first floor. This hostel does not serve breakfast. The laundry is done in the hostel dependecies and there is no parking available on site. The hostel occupies a total area of 365,49 m2 where the building itself occupies the plot of 172,65 m2. The average annual occupancy of the hostel is 58% which is equal to 6300 guest nights per year. 

This dataset is modelled to represent the service of operating a hostel. It includes: energy and water consumption, furniture and in-room textiles (such as bed linen, bed mattrasses and curtains), electric and electronic equipment used in guest rooms and on hostel premises (including bulbs), cleaning and in-room consumables. Activities include hotel operations and infrastructure based on 1 guest night stay and the lifeframe of the hotel building of 75 years. The case study hostel includes an indoor laundry facility, so laundry related environmental aspects are included in water and electricity consumption as well as cleaning consumables.

Activities end with guest departure from hotel premises. Due to data availability, the following processes have been excluded: room equipment (on-table lamp, door lock), bathroom equipment (showers, mirrors).
category: I:Accommodation and food service activities/55:Accommodation/551:Short term accommodation activities/5510:Short term accommodation activities

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The survey was done in the year 2017 with the data provided covering the operational year 2016-2017.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The hostel is based in the city of Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Technology in use is considered current.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: In terms of operations, energy and water consumption are aggregate and represent the case study hostel as a whole, rather than its specific operational areas (e.g. guest rooms, restaurant and bar). The comments to respective processes explain this in detail.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Primary data from the hotel supplemented with literature-based calculations and estimates, where appropriate.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Represents here curtains made of nylon. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hostel/lifetime of the product) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hostel * hostel occupancy rate). An average curtain is assumed to have a weight of 5 kg. Source: Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018.  Average service life of a curtain is assumed to be equal to average service life of a carpet which is 10 years. Source: Greenspec 2018. Whole life costing: carpets. Available from: http://www.greenspec.co.uk/building-design/carpets/ Accessed 16 March 2018. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste polyethylene.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hostel) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hostel * hostel occupancy rate). Combined of all instances of use across the hostel operations. Represents the following cleaning luquids: window cleaner, bleach, washing up liquid, insect killer, pine disinfector, odour eliminator. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater. As the product "cleaning consumables" is expressed as 100% active substance, the amount of cleaning consumables is multiplied by the average concentration of active substance. According to Golsteijn (2015) the average water content of cleaning consumables is 86.4%, the necessary water input is accounted for with the flow "water, compeltely softened, from decarbonised water, at user". For more information on how the cleaning consumables dataset was created please refer to the relevant dataset in ecoinvent.

2015, Laura Golsteijn, A compilation of life cycle studies for six household detergent product categories in Europe: the basis for product-specific A.I.S.E. Charter Advanced Sustainability Profiles

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. From the dataset for "cleaning consumables production" GLO 2011-2013, on average cleaning products contain 86% of water. Based on the literature source Golsteijn (2015) the dataset used to represent the water flow is "water, completely softened, at plant", version 2 dataset which corresponds to ecoinvent version 3 dataset "water, completely softened, from decarbonised waterm at user". The amount of water needed is therefore calculated based on the vale of 86% calculated based on Golsteijn (2015) and the amount of cleaning consumable which are expressed as 100% active substance.

Laura Golsteijn, 2015, A compilation of life cycle studies for six household detergent product categories in Europe: the basis for product-specific A.I.S.E. Charter Advanced Sustainability Profiles

exchanges.description: Data from the hostel survey. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hostel) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hostel * hostel occupancy rate). The amount also includes electricity requirements to produce cotton textile products from raw cotton. It is estimated that 2 MJ of electricity is required to produce 1 kg of cotton textile product. This accounts for 10% fabric loss in the cotton textile manufacturing process. Source: Baydar, G., Ciliz, N., and Mammadov, A., 2015. Life cycle assessment of cotton textile products in Turkey. Journal of Cleaner Production, 104(A), 213-223.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hostel) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hostel * hostel occupancy rate). Conversion from meters to kg has been made assuming a roll of 25 meters weights 250 g, so 1 kg of tissue paper is equal to 100 meters. Source:  Sainsburys 2018. Andrex Toilet Paper. Available from: https://www.sainsburys.co.uk/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/gb/groceries/andrex-toilet-tissue--classic-white-16x241-sheets?langId=44&storeId=10151&krypto=6KE3AoChB8jlwzzYGlgparsN%2BBruZBOjUaSVm%2BCnwAT0LLJPLAalDm9DhCtUDzK5uFGmUkJJ%2FMIaDVx%2BGRGKIHdBUxaNbCTzmIQiBcpr497qZYrRt4Kvvy%2BLLO40d8j3%2BY4eQ%2Fk%2BK4BXsq0FOjWLrDLelOp5CVxrDysmNwGM26k%3D&ddkey=https%3Agb%2Fgroceries%2Fandrex-toilet-tissue--classic-white-16x241-sheets Accessed 16 January 2018. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to wastewater.

exchanges.description: Calculated value from the total number of linen units used by the hotel. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hostel/lifetime of the product) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hostel * hostel occupancy rate). It is assumed that, on average, 4 linen units make 1 kg in weight. Source: Filimonau et al. 2011. Reviewing the carbon footprint analysis of hotels: Life Cycle Energy Analysis (LCEA) as a holistic method for carbon impact appraisal of tourist accommodation. Journal of Cleaner Production, 19, 1917-1930. Assumed average service life is 1 year (data from survey). The amount accounts for 10% fabric loss in the cotton textile manufacturing process. Source: Baydar, G., Ciliz, N., and Mammadov, A., 2015. Life cycle assessment of cotton textile products in Turkey. Journal of Cleaner Production, 104(A), 213-223.

exchanges.description:
Estimated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hostel/lifetime of the product) / (number of guests during the lifetime of the hostel * hostel occupancy rate). Assumed average service life of all pieces of furniture is 15 years. This represents service life of an average piece of furniture. Source: European Commission 2013. BACKGROUND REPORT. Revision of Ecolabel and Green Public Procurement criteria for the product group Wooden Furniture. September 2013. Available from: http://susproc.jrc.ec.europa.eu/furniture/docs/Background_report_Furniture_September_2013.pdf Accessed 19 March 2018. 
This exchange represents the following: Double bed (unit) is assumed to have a weight of 25 kg, no headboard, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Sofas (unit) Sofa is assumed to have a weight of 37 kg, two seater, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Tables/Desks (unit) Table is assumed to have a weight of 23 kg, medium, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Wardrobe (unit) is assumed to have a weight of 55 kg (double wardrobe), Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Chairs (unit) Chair is assumed to have a weight of 7 kg, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Coat stand is assumed to have a weight of 5 kg, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. Shelves are assumed to have weight of 35 kg, http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdfBunk bed (unit) Bunk bed is assumed to have a weight of 50 kg, no headboard, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Represents here 14 chairs and 1 shelf made of steel. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hostel/lifetime of the product) / (lifetime capacity). Steel chair (unit) is assumed to have a weight of 12 kg, Furniture re-use Network, 2009. Average weights. Available from: http://democracy.york.gov.uk/documents/s2116/Annex%20C%20REcycling%20Report%20frnweights2005.pdf Accessed 13 January 2018. The shelf was assumed to weight the same amount as one steel chair. Average service life of all pieces of furniture is assumed to be equal to 15 years. This represents service life of an average piece of furniture. Source: European Commission 2013. BACKGROUND REPORT. Revision of Ecolabel and Green Public Procurement criteria for the product group Wooden Furniture. September 2013. Available from: http://susproc.jrc.ec.europa.eu/furniture/docs/Background_report_Furniture_September_2013.pdf Accessed 19 March 2018. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to scrap steel.
